lines.text: You kissed me and I was thrilled!
A kiss? What does that prove? It's like finding out you can light a stove. It doesn't make you a cook.
Okay, so I've sewn a few wild oats.
A few? You could qualify for a farm loan!
At last, I've given the world what it needs! A good 10-cent drunk!
Mmm. This isn't bad, either. But what color's that floor?
Lilac.
Lilac? Leonard, who has a lilac floor in their kitchen?
I have.
Oh. Well, Leonard, everyone isn't as artistic as you are. We have to sell this wax to ordinary, everyday people.
Ugh, them.
I told you sex would get you in nothing but trouble.

[Jerry Webster enters wearing a woman's full length mink coat, and passes Fred, again]
He's the last guy in the world I woulda' figured.
You're going up there to have my baby. My son. And I'm...
It's *my* baby and I'll have what I like. And I've decided I'm having a girl.
Have whatever you like. I love you both. Now will you marry me?
You listen to me, no alcoholic beverage, no drug known to science, no torture yet devised could induce me to stay married to you!
Doctor, there's so much I can learn from you.
As my father, the philosopher, used to say, "Knock at my door and I shall take you in."
Dr. Tyler, I'm knocking.
Miss Templeton, I'm taking you in.
What are you doing up there, Peter?
I'm the king of the elevator.
And as dad always said, "A man who can't be bribed can't be trusted."
Isn't it comforting to know that you can trust me?
Think he'll like it?
Well if he doesn't, he's been taking the wrong kind of chemicals.
No, I find him very intriguing... in a man-to-man sort of way.
Your trouble is that you're still living in the shadow of your father. You're even afraid to get rid of his old car.

You don't realize how completely he dominated me ever since I was a little boy. Just once I spoke back to him. He cut a switch from a tree and gave me such a whipping, in front of this girl. It was a shattering experience.
Pete, all kids get whippings.
But I was twenty five, the girl was my fiancé.

[of sex]
It's like olives, dear. It's something you aquire a taste for.

[Carol screams]
Now stop that! You're my wife!
Some girls just aren't ready for marriage.
Congratulate me, boy. I've saved the day! I've been working with my lawyers and we've come up with an ironclad document that will hold up in any court. This solves everything.
Great. What is it?
A full and complete confession. Sign.
Are you kidding? I could go to jail for five years.
No. That's covered in here. We make a deal with the judge. Two years. Sign.
[Puts pen in Jerry's hand]
Forget it.
[throws pen down]
Two years! It's like being drafted. Think of me as your commander in chief. Greetings from the president. Sign.
[puts pen back in Jerry's hand and tries to manipulate it to force a signature]
I couldn't find Dr. Tyler anywhere. The guy has disappeared.
That tears it!
Hadley?
[Opens window]
Step over to the window.
Mr. Ramsey I told you. I am not going to jump!
You don't have to jump. I'll trip you. Huh? Double indemnity. Your wife will be loaded. Kids'll go to college. Right? Come on, boy! Run!
[holds up his leg in front of the window]
Pete, knock it off!

[Spoken to Jerry and Hadley]
I'm surrounded by traitors!
I've only seen him a dozen or so times.
Well, what's your opinion?
I prefer to reserve judgment till I see him sober.
Oh! Doesn't that tell you what he is?
Miss Templeton, as my uncle, the missionary, used to say, "If thou canst not speak well of a man, speak not at all."
You make me feel ashamed of myself.

[Carol realises the problem with the product is it's packaging, and has to convince Leonard and Millie how important it is to stay late and finish working on it]
Believe me; the agency that lands this account, is the one who shows Mr. Miller the most attractive can.
[Carol picks up a can of wax]
[immeditely cuts to the next shot; a line of dancing 'rabbit-girls' derierres]

[Pete makes his best friend/employee, Jerry, call Carol and apologise, hoping she'll withdraw her complaint she filed with the Advertising Council. As Jerry's places the call, Pete paces nervously next to him]
Carol Templeton, please.

[to Jerry]
Assure her of our high moral,character.

[Carol Templeton appears on split-screen, a la Pillow Talk. She speaks in a 'too professional' voice]
Yes, Mister Webster?
A Mr. Ramsey, here, tells me that you spoke to him, and I'd like to ask you a favour; will you kindly keep your big, fat nose out of my business?

[Starts screaming at Jerry in a strangled voice]
No, no!
If the competition's too tough, get out of the advertising profession.
You aren't even IN the 'advertising profession.' And if I weren't a lady, I'd tell you what profession you ARE in!

[Trying to goad Carol]
Tell me, anyway.
Well, let me put it this way; I don't use sex to land an account!

[Looking straight at the camera, and smirking]
When do you use it?
I don't!
My condolences to your husband.

[Carol's eyes narrow, and she seethes as she speaks]
I'm NOT married.
That figures.

[Caught off guard]
What - What do you mean, 'that figures'?
Well, a husband would be competition. There's only room for one man in the family.
Let me tell you something, Mr. Webster
[Carol takes a deep breath, and raises a fist]
I wish I were a man, right now!

[Sneering]
Keep trying. I think you'll make it.
[Carol slams down the phone]

[Jerry's boss - and friend - Pete - is making him ring Carol Templeton to apologise - and hopefully have her withdraw her complaint to the Advertising Council]
Carol Templeton, please, Jerry Webster calling.
[Speaking to the operator]
Ramsey & Son.
Assure her of our high moral character

[On split-screen]
Yes, mister Webster?
Mr. Ramsey, here, tells me that you spoke to him, and I'd like to,ask you a favour; will you kindly keep,your big, fat nose out of my business?
[Pete starts getting furious, yelling in a strangled voice 'no, no,' at Jerry, who ignores him]
If the comoetition's too tough, get out of the advertising profession.
[Pete's got his hands in his face]
YOU aren't even IN the advertising profession, and if I weren't a lady, I'd tell you what profession you ARE in.
Tell me, anyway

[Thinking she's got the upper-hand, tries to talk 'down' to Jerry]
Well, let me put it this way; I don't use sex to land an account.
When do you use it
I don't.
My condolences to your husband

[Carol's eyes narrow, and she's seething with anger as she speaks]
I'm NOT married.
Ths figures.
What, what do you mean, 'that figures'?
Well, a husband would be competition. There's only room for one man in the family.

[Carol's steaming, and trying to stay calm]
Oooh! Let me tell,you,something, mister Webster; I wish I were a man, right now,

[Goading Carol]
Keep trying, I think you'll make it.
[Carole looks at the phone's receiver, and hangs it up, forcefully]

[Pete blows a bull horn]
What's that?
The mating call of the moose.
[Pete blows the bull horn again]
This call is absolutely irresistible. Your bull moose will run for twenty miles, he will crash through any barrier to get to the source of this call.
[Blows horn, yet again]
And what happens if he gets there?
I take his picture
Pete, he's not running twenty miles to get photographed. Now I suggest you stop blowing that horn.
This'll be the biggest scandal that hit Madison Avenue. The agency's through. We're ruined. There's only one way out; suicide.
All right... All right...
We'll get Hadley to commit suicide, and we pin the blame on him.
You may have a little trouble selling that idea to Hadley.
He wouldn't dare refuse. His job depends on it.
